content: Eligibility for health benefits under CHIP is available to different groups through various federal authorities and mechanisms. This includes children, pregnant women, parents, and childless adults who may be covered under the CHIP state plan or special waiver authority. States can define a targeted low-income child as someone under 19 without health insurance, with income levels up to 200% of the federal poverty level. States have the flexibility to expand eligibility for all children under 19, but higher-income CHIP children may see reduced federal payments under CHIPRA. CHIPRA reduces federal CHIP payments for higher-income CHIP children, using the regular Medicaid FMAP for those with family income over 300% of poverty. States can cover these children under Medicaid or create a separate CHIP program. Medicaid rules apply for Medicaid coverage, while Title XXI rules apply for separate CHIP programs. Title XXI rules apply when states provide coverage to targeted low-income children through separate CHIP programs, with federal CHIP funds covering program costs. States with approved state CHIP plans receive federal allotments based on a distribution formula. Targeted low-income children covered under a CHIP-financed Medicaid expansion are entitled to benefits as per Medicaid law, while no individual entitlement exists for those covered under separate CHIP programs. States can expand Medicaid for targeted low-income children by creating new eligibility groups authorized in Title XXI. States can cover targeted low-income children under Medicaid by creating new eligibility groups authorized in Title XXI or by establishing separate CHIP programs. The latter option reduces administrative burden by utilizing existing Medicaid eligibility pathways. States have flexibility in determining eligibility factors such as geography, age, income, and resources for targeted low-income children. States have flexibility in determining eligibility factors for targeted low-income children under separate CHIP programs, including geography, age, income, resources, residency, disability status, access to other health insurance, and duration of CHIP eligibility. Prior to CHIPRA, states could cover adult pregnant women through waivers, CHIP state plan amendments, or family coverage options. States have the flexibility to provide health benefits coverage, including prenatal care and delivery services, to unborn children of adult pregnant women through CHIP state plan amendments. The period of coverage for pregnant women under CHIP is from pregnancy through the postpartum period. Benefits include all services available to CHIP children, prenatal, delivery, and postpartum care. Infants born to these pregnant women are eligible for Medicaid or CHIP up to age one year. Legal immigrants arriving in the United States after August 22, 1996, were ineligible for Medicaid or CHIP benefits for their first five years here. CHIPRA clarified that states can offer postpartum services to legal immigrants who were previously ineligible for Medicaid or CHIP benefits for their first five years in the United States. The law requires consideration of the sponsor's income and resources for legal immigrants, and the sponsor is financially responsible for the individual. States must redetermine eligibility every 12 months and individuals must provide further documentation if their initial legal residence documentation is no longer valid. Under current law, Section 1115 of the Social Security Act gives the Secretary of Health and Human Services broad authority to modify aspects of the CHIP programs, including expanding eligibility to populations not otherwise eligible. Certain states have covered adults with CHIP funds through waivers, initially effective for five years and subject to renewal every three years. Waiver renewals for states with adult coverage have not been approved since 2007, leading to some states transitioning adult populations out of CHIP coverage. Waiver renewals for states with adult coverage under CHIP have not been approved since 2007, leading to some states transitioning adult populations out of CHIP coverage. States with existing childless adult waivers that were in effect during FY2009 are permitted to apply for Medicaid waivers to continue coverage for these individuals. CHIPRA requires budget neutrality standards for succeeding fiscal years to be tied to waiver spending in the preceding fiscal year. Coverage of parents is permitted for states with CHIP parent coverage waivers that were in effect during FY2009. Beginning in FY2012, allowable spending under the waivers will be subject to a set-aside amount from a separate allotment and will be matched at the state's regular Medicaid FMAP unless certain coverage benchmarks are met. In FY2013, states meeting the benchmarks will receive an amount between the regular and enhanced FMAPs for parents. Waiver spending under the set-aside for parents with family income exceeding eligibility thresholds as of February 4, 2009 is prohibited. CHIPRA also includes provisions to facilitate access and enrollment in Medicaid and CHIP. CHIPRA includes provisions for outreach and enrollment in Medicaid and CHIP, authorizing $100 million in grants for outreach campaigns. Funds will be directed towards a national enrollment campaign, outreach for Native American children, and initiatives targeting rural areas and underserved populations. Grant proposals addressing cultural and linguistic barriers to enrollment will also be prioritized. Additionally, CHIPRA requires states to describe procedures for reducing administrative barriers to enrollment for children and pregnant women in Medicaid and CHIP. The new law requires dental services to be a benefit under separate CHIP programs, including preventive care, restoration of oral health, and treatment for emergency conditions. Federal financing of CHIP includes appropriations, reallocation of funds, and other factors like matching rates and caps. The federal financing of the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) includes total appropriations for states' annual allotments, reallocation of funds, and other factors like matching rates and caps on expenses. The funding levels varied over fiscal years, with a total of approximately $40 billion appropriated for FY1998 to FY2007. The funding dropped in FY2002-FY2004, known as the "CHIP dip," due to budget constraints. The 110th Congress passed bills to reauthorize CHIP, providing funding for FY2008 through FY2012. Bush vetoed both bills, leading to the Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Extension Act of 2007 appropriating funds for CHIP allotments for FY2008 and FY2009. The CHIP allotments are determined by a formula based on low-income and uninsured children. Each state's allotment is adjusted by a geographic factor and limited by floors and ceilings. CHIPRA created a Child Enrollment Contingency Fund to prevent states from experiencing federal CHIP fund shortfalls, with direct payments to shortfall states not exceeding 20% of the national allotment amount. The Contingency Fund provides payments to states for CHIP children above target enrollment levels, capped at 20% of the national allotment. CHIP is a federal-state matching program with a state's share of expenditures for Medicaid determined by the federal medical assistance percentage (FMAP). The enhanced FMAP for CHIP reduces a state's share by 30% compared to the regular FMAP. The enhanced FMAP for CHIP ranges from 65% to 83.09%, and all CHIP assistance for low-income children is eligible for this enhanced FMAP. The enhanced FMAP for CHIP ranges from 65% to 83.09%, with a ceiling of 85% and a floor of 65%.
